newsitem.title: USA: Taxpayers sue California over budget impasse.
newsitem.headline: Taxpayers sue California over budget impasse.

text.p: A coalition of California taxpayers sued Governor Pete Wilson on Friday, seeking to block the state from paying lawmakers and state workers during the state's budget impasse.

The lawsuit, filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court, alleged that California's Constitution bars the state from paying the governor, legislators and approximately 250,000 state workers when no budget is in place.

"Not only are the legislators acting illegally, but their actions are injuring all Californians since no one, other than the legislators and state employees, is being paid," plaintiffs' attorney Richard Fine said in a statement.

"All other people who are owed money by the state, such as small and minority businesses, other vendors and creditors of the state and recipients of promised aid, are being required to wait for the money the state owes them," he said.
A spokesman for the governor was not immediately available to comment.
The state's Constitutional budget deadline was June 15, but state lawmakers have yet to approve a spending plan for the 1997-1998 fiscal year, which began on July 1.
The taxpayer lawsuit, entitled Steven White v. Pete Wilson, seeks an injunction to prevent the state from paying workers until a budget is passed.
White is chairman of the Steering Committee of the Committees of Correspondence, a coalition of taxpayer groups.
